newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Gasunie likely to take UK gas via Belgian network.
newsitem.headline: Gasunie likely to take UK gas via Belgian network.

text.p: Dutch gas distributor Gasunie confirmed on Wednesday it would not be building a pipeline in Belgium and, at least in the short-term, would probably rely on the Belgian network to receive British gas.
"We have written to (Belgian gas distributor) Distrigas and to the Belgian government that we will not be building a pipeline through Belgium," a Gasunie spokesman said.

The spokesman said Gasunie was considering three options to provide a link with Britain, but only two would be available to receive British gas when the Interconnector pipeline, connecting Britain with the continent, opens in October 1998.

Gasunie will ask Distrigas to transport gas to the Dutch border or it will close a deal with a U.K. supplier which would have to arrange transport through Belgium, most likely via the Distrigas network.
A third option, under study, is to build a pipeline from Den Helder on the Dutch coast to Bacton in Britain.

"We expect the feasibility study to be ready early next year and (the pipeline) could be built a few years after that. It would be mainly a capacity pipeline for gas from the continent to the U.K.," the spokesman said.
He added the pipe would probably receive gas from Britain for three to four years after which Britain should become a net importer of gas.
Gasunie is fifty percent owned by the Dutch state and 25 percent each by Royal Dutch/Shell and Exxon Corp.
